longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: An Ordinance to prohibit conduct that prevents, restricts or distorts competition in Hong Kong; to prohibit mergers that substantially lessen competition in Hong Kong; to establish a Competition Commission and a Competition Tribunal; and to provide for incidental and connected matters.

subsection.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Competition Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance—
subsection.def: agreement (協議) includes any agreement, arrangement, understanding, promise or undertaking, whether express or implied, written or oral, and whether or not enforceable or intended to be enforceable by legal proceedings;
Communications Authority (通訊事務管理局) means the Communications Authority established by section 3 of the Communications Authority Ordinance (Cap. 616);

company (公司), in addition to the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622), includes a non-Hong Kong company within the meaning of that Ordinance and a company registered under Part IX of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 32) as in force from time to time before the commencement date* of section 2 of Schedule 9 to the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) or under Part 17 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622); (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920 and L.N. 162 of 2013)
company secretary (公司秘書) includes any person occupying the position of company secretary, by whatever name called;

def.name: CompetitionAuthority
def.leadIn: competition authority (競爭事務當局) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commission; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Communications Authority;

def.name: CompetitionMatter
def.leadIn: competition matter (競爭事宜) means any matter involving or having a connection with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a contravention or alleged contravention of a competition rule; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any decision relating to a competition rule, that has been made or is to be made under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the first conduct rule;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the second conduct rule; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the merger rule;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the first conduct rule; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the second conduct rule;

subsection.def: confidential information (機密資料) has the meaning given by section 123;

contract of employment (僱傭合約) means any agreement, whether in writing or oral, express or implied, under which one person (an employer) agrees to employ another and that other agrees to serve the employer as an employee, and also includes a contract of apprenticeship;
director (董事) includes any person occupying the position of director or involved in the management of a company, by whatever name called, and includes a shadow director;
first conduct rule (第一行為守則) has the meaning given by section 6;
funds of the Commission (競委會資金) means the funds of the Commission, as specified in section 21 of Schedule 5;
infringement notice (違章通知書) means an infringement notice issued under section 67(2);
leniency agreement (寬待協議) means a leniency agreement made under section 80;
merger (合併) has the meaning given by section 3 of Schedule 7 read together with section 5 of that Schedule;
merger rule (合併守則) has the meaning given by section 3 of Schedule 7;
reviewable determination (可覆核裁定) has the meaning given by section 83;
second conduct rule (第二行為守則) has the meaning given by section 21;

def.name: SeriousAnticompetitiveConduct
def.leadIn: serious anti-competitive conduct (嚴重反競爭行為) means any conduct that consists of any of the following or any combination of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fixing, maintaining, increasing or controlling the price for the supply of goods or services;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: allocating sales, territories, customers or markets for the production or supply of goods or services;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: fixing, maintaining, controlling, preventing, limiting or eliminating the production or supply of goods or services;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: bid-rigging;

subsection.def: shadow director (幕後董事), in relation to a company, means a person in accordance with whose directions or instructions all the directors or a majority of the directors of the company are accustomed to act, but a person is not to be regarded as a shadow director by reason only that all the directors or a majority of the directors act on advice given by that person in a professional capacity;

def.name: StatutoryBody
def.leadIn: statutory body (法定團體) means a body of persons, corporate or unincorporate, established or constituted by or under an Ordinance or appointed under an Ordinance, but does not include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a corporation of trustees incorporated under the Registered Trustees Incorporation Ordinance (Cap. 306);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a society registered under the Societies Ordinance (Cap. 151);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a co-operative society registered under the Co-operative Societies Ordinance (Cap. 33); or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a trade union registered under the Trade Unions Ordinance (Cap. 332);

subsection.def: undertaking (業務實體) means any entity, regardless of its legal status or the way in which it is financed, engaged in economic activity, and includes a natural person engaged in economic activity.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of the definition of serious anti-competitive conduct—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: an agreement—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that is made between or among 2 or more undertakings whereby one or more of those undertakings agrees or undertakes not to submit a bid or tender in response to a call or request for bids or tenders, or agrees or undertakes to withdraw a bid or tender submitted in response to such a call or request; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that is not made known to the person calling for or requesting bids or tenders at or before the time when a bid or tender is submitted or withdrawn by a party to the agreement or by an entity controlled by any one or more of the parties to the agreement; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a submission, in response to a call or request for bids or tenders, of bids or tenders that are arrived at by an agreement—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that is made between or among 2 or more undertakings; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that is not made known to the person calling for or requesting bids or tenders at or before the time when a bid or tender is submitted or withdrawn by a party to the agreement or by an entity controlled by any one or more of the parties to the agreement;

subsection.def: goods (貨品) includes real property;
price (價格) includes any discount, rebate, allowance, price concession or other advantage in relation to the supply of goods or services;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to goods, means sell, rent, lease or otherwise dispose of the goods, an interest in the goods or a right to the goods, or offer so to dispose of the goods or of such an interest or right; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to services, means sell, rent or otherwise provide the services or offer so to provide the services.

subsection.content: A note located in the text of this Ordinance is provided for information only and has no legislative effect.

subsection.leadIn: The following provisions do not apply to a statutory body—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Part 2 (The conduct rules);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Part 4 (Enforcement powers of Commission);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Part 6 (Enforcement before Tribunal); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: Schedule 7 (Mergers).

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1), the provisions referred to in that subsection apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a specified statutory body; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a statutory body, to the extent that it is engaged in a specified activity.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.def: specified (指明) means specified in a regulation made for the purpose of this section by the Chief Executive in Council under section 5; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a reference to a statutory body includes an employee or agent of the statutory body, acting in that capacity.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Application to specified persons and persons engaged in specified activities

subsection.leadIn: The provisions referred to in section 3(1) do not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a specified person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person, to the extent that the person is engaged in a specified activity.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.def: specified (指明) means specified in a regulation made for the purpose of this section by the Chief Executive in Council under section 5; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a reference to a person includes an employee or agent of the person, acting in that capacity.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may, by regulation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: apply the provisions referred to in section 3(1) to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any statutory body; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any statutory body, to the extent that it is engaged in an activity specified in the regulation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: disapply the provisions referred to in section 3(1) to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any person; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any person, to the extent that the person is engaged in an activity specified in the regulation.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may only make a regulation under subsection (1)(a)(i) or (ii) with respect to a statutory body if he or she is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the statutory body is engaging in an economic activity in direct competition with another undertaking;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the economic activity of the statutory body is affecting the economic efficiency of a specific market;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the economic activity of the statutory body is not directly related to the provision of an essential public service or the implementation of public policy; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: there are no other exceptional and compelling reasons of public policy against making such a regulation.

subsection.content: In subsection (1), a reference to a statutory body or a person includes an employee or agent of the statutory body or person, acting in that capacity.

division.name: D1
division.heading: Agreements etc. Preventing, Restricting or Distorting Competition

section.name: s6
section.heading: Prohibition of anti-competitive agreements, concerted practices and decisions

subsection.leadIn: An undertaking must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make or give effect to an agreement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: engage in a concerted practice; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: as a member of an association of undertakings, make or give effect to a decision of the association,

subsection.continued: if the object or effect of the agreement, concerted practice or decision is to prevent, restrict or distort competition in Hong Kong.

subsection.content: Unless the context otherwise requires, a provision of this Ordinance which is expressed to apply to, or in relation to, an agreement is to be read as applying equally to, or in relation to, a concerted practice and a decision by an association of undertakings (but with any necessary modifications).
The prohibition imposed by subsection (1) is referred to in this Ordinance as the first conduct rule.

If an agreement, concerted practice or decision has more than one object, it has the object of preventing, restricting or distorting competition under this Ordinance if one of its objects is to prevent, restrict or distort competition.

An undertaking may be taken to have made or given effect to an agreement or decision or to have engaged in a concerted practice that has as its object the prevention, restriction or distortion of competition even if that object can be ascertained only by inference.

If an agreement, concerted practice or decision has more than one effect, it has the effect of preventing, restricting or distorting competition under this Ordinance if one of its effects is to prevent, restrict or distort competition.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Territorial application of first conduct rule
section.leadIn: The first conduct rule applies to an agreement, concerted practice or decision that has the object or effect of preventing, restricting or distorting competition in Hong Kong even if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the agreement or decision is made or given effect to outside Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the concerted practice is engaged in outside Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any party to the agreement or concerted practice is outside Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any undertaking or association of undertakings giving effect to a decision is outside Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: An undertaking that has made or given effect to, is giving effect to or is proposing to make or give effect to an agreement may apply to the Commission for a decision as to whether or not the agreement is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: excluded from the application of the first conduct rule by or as a result of Schedule 1;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: exempt from the application of the first conduct rule by virtue of a block exemption order issued under section 15;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: exempt from the application of the first conduct rule by virtue of an order of the Chief Executive in Council made under section 31 (Exemptions on public policy grounds) or section 32 (Exemption to avoid conflict with international obligations); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: excluded from the application of this Part by virtue of section 3 (Application to statutory bodies) or section 4 (Application to specified persons and persons engaged in specified activities).

subsection.leadIn: The Commission is only required to consider an application under this section if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the application poses novel or unresolved questions of wider importance or public interest in relation to the application of exclusions or exemptions under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the application raises a question of an exclusion or exemption under this Ordinance for which there is no clarification in existing case law or decisions of the Commission; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: it is possible to make a decision on the basis of the information provided.

subsection.content: The Commission is not required to consider an application under this section if the application concerns hypothetical questions or agreements.

subsection.leadIn: Before making a decision on an application made under section 9, the Commission must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in order to bring the application to the attention of those the Commission considers likely to be affected by the decision, publish notice of the application—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: through the Internet or a similar electronic network; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in any other manner the Commission considers appropriate; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: consider any representations about the application that are made to the Commission.

subsection.content: A notice under subsection (1) must specify the period within which representations may be made to the Commission about the application.
The period specified for the purpose of subsection (2) must be a period of at least 30 days beginning after the day on which the notice is first published.

After considering the representations, if any, made within the period referred to in section 10, the Commission may make a decision as to whether or not the agreement in question is excluded or exempt from the application of the first conduct rule or this Part.
A decision by the Commission may include conditions or limitations subject to which it is to have effect.
After the Commission has made its decision, it must inform the applicant in writing of the decision, the date of its decision and the reasons for it.

Subject to subsection (2), if the Commission makes a decision that an agreement is excluded or exempt from the application of the first conduct rule or this Part then each undertaking specified in the decision is immune from any action under this Ordinance with regard to that agreement.

The immunity provided by subsection (1) applies to an undertaking only to the extent of the first conduct rule or this Part, and in so far as that undertaking complies with every condition and limitation subject to which the decision is to have effect.

If an undertaking fails or ceases to comply with a condition or limitation subject to which a decision has effect, the immunity provided by section 12 ceases to apply with respect to that undertaking with effect from the date on which the non-compliance begins.

If an undertaking starts to comply or resumes compliance with the condition or limitation, the immunity provided by section 12 applies to that undertaking with effect from the date on which the compliance begins or resumes.

Action may be taken under this Ordinance against any undertaking relating to a contravention of the first conduct rule by that undertaking, that occurs during any period in which the immunity provided by section 12 does not apply to it.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may rescind a decision made under section 11 if it has reason to believe—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that there has been a material change of circumstances since the decision was made; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the information on which it based its decision was incomplete, false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: Before rescinding a decision under this section the Commission must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in order to bring the proposed rescission to the attention of those undertakings the Commission considers likely to be affected by it, publish notice of the proposed rescission—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: stating that the Commission is considering rescinding the decision and the reasons why it is considering the rescission; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: inviting the undertakings to make representations about the proposed rescission within the period specified in the notice; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: consider any representations received within the period specified in the notice.

subsection.leadIn: The notice referred to in subsection (2) must be published—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: through the Internet or a similar electronic network; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other manner the Commission considers appropriate.

subsection.content: The period specified in the notice published under subsection (2) must be a period of at least 30 days beginning after the day on which the notice is published.

subsection.leadIn: If, after—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the expiry of the period specified in the notice published under subsection (2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: considering any representations received within that period,

subsection.continued: the Commission is of the view that the decision should be rescinded, it may, by notice in writing given to each undertaking for which the decision provides immunity, rescind that decision.

subsection.leadIn: A notice of rescission given under subsection (5) must inform the undertakings of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the rescission and the reasons for the rescission;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date on which the determination to rescind the decision was made; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the date from which the rescission takes effect.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commission is satisfied that any information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on which it based its decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which was provided to it by a party to the agreement,

subsection.continued: was incomplete, false or misleading in a material particular, the date specified in a notice under subsection (6)(c) may be earlier than the date on which the notice is given.

subsection.content: If a decision is rescinded under this section, each undertaking specified in the notice of rescission loses its immunity from action under this Ordinance, as from the date the rescission takes effect, with regard to anything done after that date.
A rescission of a decision under this section may be made with regard to all of the undertakings for which the decision provides immunity or with regard to only one or more of them.
If the Commission is satisfied that a particular category of agreement is an excluded agreement, it may issue a block exemption order in respect of that category of agreement.
The Commission may, either of its own volition or on application by an undertaking or an association of undertakings, issue a block exemption order.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may, in a block exemption order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: impose conditions or limitations subject to which the block exemption order is to have effect; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify a date from which the order is to cease to have effect.

subsection.content: The Commission must, in a block exemption order, specify a date, being a date not more than 5 years after the date of the order, upon which it will commence a review of the block exemption order.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: excluded agreement (豁除協議) means an agreement that is excluded from the application of the first conduct rule by or as a result of section 1 (Agreements enhancing overall economic efficiency) of Schedule 1.

subsection.leadIn: Before issuing a block exemption order, the Commission must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in order to bring the proposed block exemption order to the attention of those the Commission considers likely to be affected by it, publish notice of the proposed block exemption order—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: through the Internet or a similar electronic network; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in any other manner the Commission considers appropriate; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: consider any representations about the proposed block exemption order that are made to the Commission.

subsection.content: A notice under subsection (1) must specify the period within which representations may be made to the Commission about the proposed block exemption order.
The period specified for the purpose of subsection (2) must be a period of at least 30 days beginning after the day on which the notice is first published.
Subject to subsection (2), an agreement that falls within a category of agreement specified in a block exemption order is exempt from the application of the first conduct rule.

The immunity provided by subsection (1) to undertakings making or giving effect to an agreement applies to an undertaking only if it complies with every condition and limitation subject to which the block exemption order has effect.

If an undertaking fails or ceases to comply with a condition or limitation subject to which a block exemption order has effect, the block exemption order ceases to apply with respect to that undertaking with effect from the date on which the non-compliance begins.

If an undertaking starts to comply or resumes compliance with the condition or limitation, the block exemption order applies to that undertaking with effect from the date on which the compliance begins or resumes.

Action may be taken under this Ordinance against any undertaking relating to a contravention of the first conduct rule by that undertaking, that occurs during any period in which the block exemption order does not apply to it.
The Commission must commence a review of a block exemption order on the date specified in the order for the commencement of the review.
Despite subsection (1), the Commission may review a block exemption order at any time if it considers it appropriate to do so.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the matters that may be considered in deciding, under subsection (2), whether or not to review a block exemption order, the Commission must consider the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the desirability of maintaining a stable and predictable regulatory environment in relation to competition;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any developments that have taken place in the economy of Hong Kong or in the economy of any place outside Hong Kong that affect the category of agreement that is the subject of the block exemption order; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whether any significant new information relating to the particular category of agreement has come to the knowledge of the Commission since the block exemption order was first issued.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Variation or revocation of block exemption order

subsection.content: If the Commission considers that it is appropriate to do so, after reviewing a block exemption order, it may issue an order varying or revoking the block exemption order with effect from a date specified in the order.

subsection.leadIn: Before varying or revoking a block exemption order, the Commission must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in order to bring the proposed variation or revocation to the attention of those the Commission considers likely to be affected by it, publish notice of the proposed variation or revocation—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: through the Internet or a similar electronic network; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in any other manner the Commission considers appropriate; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: consider any representations about the proposed variation or revocation that are made to the Commission.

subsection.content: A notice under subsection (2) must specify the period within which representations may be made to the Commission about the proposed variation or revocation.
The period specified for the purpose of subsection (3) must be a period of at least 30 days beginning after the day on which the notice is first published.

subsection.leadIn: An order made under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must specify the date on which it is to have effect; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may contain any transitional and savings provisions the Commission considers necessary or expedient.

subsection.content: An undertaking that has a substantial degree of market power in a market must not abuse that power by engaging in conduct that has as its object or effect the prevention, restriction or distortion of competition in Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of subsection (1), conduct may, in particular, constitute such an abuse if it involves—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: predatory behaviour towards competitors; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: limiting production, markets or technical development to the prejudice of consumers.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the matters that may be taken into account in determining whether an undertaking has a substantial degree of market power in a market, the following matters may be taken into consideration in any such determination—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the market share of the undertaking;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the undertaking’s power to make pricing and other decisions;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any barriers to entry to competitors into the relevant market; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other relevant matters specified in the guidelines issued under section 35 for the purposes of this paragraph.

subsection.content: The prohibition imposed by subsection (1) is referred to in this Ordinance as the second conduct rule.
If conduct has more than one object, it has the object of preventing, restricting or distorting competition under this Ordinance if one of its objects is to prevent, restrict or distort competition.
An undertaking may be taken to have engaged in conduct that has as its object the prevention, restriction or distortion of competition even if that object can be ascertained only by inference.
If conduct has more than one effect, it has the effect of preventing, restricting or distorting competition under this Ordinance if one of its effects is to prevent, restrict or distort competition.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Territorial application of second conduct rule
section.leadIn: The second conduct rule applies to conduct that has as its object or effect the prevention, restriction or distortion of competition in Hong Kong even if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the undertaking engaging in the conduct is outside Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the conduct is engaged in outside Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: An undertaking that has engaged in, is engaging in or is proposing to engage in certain conduct may apply to the Commission for a decision as to whether or not the conduct is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: excluded from the application of the second conduct rule by or as a result of Schedule 1;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: exempt from the application of the second conduct rule by virtue of an order of the Chief Executive in Council made under section 31 (Exemptions on public policy grounds) or section 32 (Exemption to avoid conflict with international obligations); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: excluded from the application of this Part by virtue of section 3 (Application to statutory bodies) or section 4 (Application to specified persons and persons engaged in specified activities).

subsection.leadIn: The Commission is only required to consider an application under this section if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the application poses novel or unresolved questions of wider importance or public interest in relation to the application of exclusions or exemptions under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the application raises a question of an exclusion or exemption under this Ordinance for which there is no clarification in existing case law or decisions of the Commission; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: it is possible to make a decision on the basis of the information provided.

subsection.content: The Commission is not required to consider an application under this section if the application concerns hypothetical questions or conduct.

subsection.leadIn: Before making a decision on an application made under section 24, the Commission must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in order to bring the application to the attention of those the Commission considers likely to be affected by the decision, publish notice of the application—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: through the Internet or a similar electronic network; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in any other manner the Commission considers appropriate; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: consider any representations about the application that are made to the Commission.

subsection.content: A notice under subsection (1) must specify the period within which representations may be made to the Commission about the application.
The period specified for the purpose of subsection (2) must be a period of at least 30 days beginning after the day on which the notice is first published.

After considering the representations, if any, made within the period referred to in section 25, the Commission may make a decision as to whether or not the conduct in question is excluded or exempt from the application of the second conduct rule or this Part.
A decision by the Commission may include conditions or limitations subject to which it is to have effect.
After the Commission has made its decision, it must inform the applicant in writing of the decision, the date of its decision and the reasons for it.

Subject to subsection (2), if the Commission makes a decision that conduct is excluded or exempt from the application of the second conduct rule or this Part then each undertaking specified in the decision is immune from any action under this Ordinance with regard to that conduct.

The immunity provided by subsection (1) applies to an undertaking only to the extent of the second conduct rule or this Part, and in so far as that undertaking complies with every condition and limitation subject to which the decision is to have effect.

If an undertaking fails or ceases to comply with a condition or limitation subject to which a decision has effect, the immunity provided by section 27 ceases to apply with respect to that undertaking with effect from the date on which the non-compliance begins.

If an undertaking starts to comply or resumes compliance with the condition or limitation, the immunity provided by section 27 applies to that undertaking with effect from the date on which the compliance begins or resumes.

Action may be taken under this Ordinance against any undertaking relating to a contravention of the second conduct rule by that undertaking, that occurs during any period in which the immunity provided by section 27 does not apply to it.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may rescind a decision made under section 26 if it has reason to believe—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that there has been a material change of circumstances since the decision was made; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the information on which it based its decision was incomplete, false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: Before rescinding a decision under this section the Commission must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in order to bring the proposed rescission to the attention of those undertakings the Commission considers likely to be affected by it, publish notice of the proposed rescission—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: stating that the Commission is considering rescinding the decision and the reasons why it is considering the rescission; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: inviting the undertakings to make representations about the proposed rescission within the period specified in the notice; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: consider any representations received within the period specified in the notice.

subsection.leadIn: The notice referred to in subsection (2) must be published—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: through the Internet or a similar electronic network; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other manner the Commission considers appropriate.

subsection.content: The period specified in the notice published under subsection (2) must be a period of at least 30 days beginning after the day on which the notice is published.

subsection.leadIn: If, after—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the expiry of the period specified in the notice published under subsection (2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: considering any representations received within that period,

subsection.continued: the Commission is of the view that the decision should be rescinded, it may, by notice in writing given to each undertaking for which the decision provides immunity, rescind that decision.

subsection.leadIn: A notice of rescission given under subsection (5) must inform the undertakings of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the rescission and the reasons for the rescission;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date on which the determination to rescind the decision was made; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the date from which the rescission takes effect.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commission is satisfied that any information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on which it based its decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which was provided to it by an undertaking engaging in the conduct,

subsection.continued: was incomplete, false or misleading in a material particular, the date specified in a notice under subsection (6)(c) may be earlier than the date on which the notice is given.

subsection.content: If a decision is rescinded under this section, each undertaking specified in the notice of rescission loses its immunity from action under this Ordinance, as from the date the rescission takes effect, with regard to anything done after that date.
A rescission of a decision under this section may be made with regard to all of the undertakings for which the decision provides immunity or with regard to only one or more of them.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Exclusions
section.content: The conduct rules do not apply in any of the cases in which they are excluded by or as a result of Schedule 1.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may, by order published in the Gazette, exempt—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a specified agreement or a specified class of agreement from the application of the first conduct rule; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specified conduct or a specified class of conduct from the application of the second conduct rule,

subsection.continued: if he or she is satisfied that there are exceptional and compelling reasons of public policy for doing so.

subsection.content: An order under subsection (1) may be made subject to any conditions or limitations that the Chief Executive in Council considers appropriate.
An order made under this section remains in force for the period that is specified in the order.
Before the expiry of an order, the Chief Executive in Council may, by order published in the Gazette, extend the period of its validity.
An order made under subsection (1) may provide that the conduct rule in question has never applied to any agreement or conduct specified in the order.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Exemption to avoid conflict with international obligations

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may, by order published in the Gazette, exempt—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a specified agreement or a specified class of agreement from the application of the first conduct rule; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specified conduct or a specified class of conduct from the application of the second conduct rule,

subsection.continued: if he or she is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so, in order to avoid a conflict between this Ordinance and an international obligation that directly or indirectly relates to Hong Kong.

subsection.content: An order under subsection (1) may be made subject to any conditions or limitations that the Chief Executive in Council considers appropriate.
An order made under this section remains in force for the period that is specified in the order.
Before the expiry of an order, the Chief Executive in Council may, by order published in the Gazette, extend the period of its validity.

If an international obligation has ceased to have effect or has been varied, the Chief Executive in Council may, by order published in the Gazette, revoke an order made under this section, or (as the case requires) amend it to the extent warranted by the variation.
An order made under subsection (1) may provide that the conduct rule in question has never applied to any agreement or conduct specified in the order.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: InternationalObligation
def.leadIn: international obligation (國際義務) includes an obligation under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an air service agreement or a provisional arrangement referred to in Article 133 of the Basic Law;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an international arrangement relating to civil aviation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any agreement, provisional arrangement or international arrangement designated as an international agreement, international provisional arrangement or international arrangement by the Chief Executive in Council by order published in the Gazette.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Orders to be published and placed before Legislative Council

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive is to arrange for every order made under section 31 or 32 to be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: published in the Gazette; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: laid on the table of the Legislative Council at the next sitting of the Council after its publication in the Gazette.

subsection.content: The Legislative Council may, by resolution passed at a sitting of the Legislative Council held not later than 28 days after the sitting at which an order is laid on the table of the Council (the relevant period), amend the order in any manner consistent with the power of the Chief Executive in Council to make the order in question.

If the relevant period would but for this section expire after the end of a session or a dissolution of the Legislative Council, but on or before the day of its second sitting in the next session, the period for amending the order is deemed to be extended and to expire on the day after that second sitting.

The Legislative Council may, before the expiry of the relevant period, by resolution extend the period for amending the order to the first sitting of the Council held not earlier than the twenty-first day after the day of that expiry.

If the relevant period is extended under subsection (3), the Legislative Council may, before the expiry of the extended period, by resolution extend that extended period to the first sitting of the Council held not earlier than the twenty-first day after the day of the second sitting in the next session referred to in that subsection.

A resolution passed by the Legislative Council in accordance with this section must be published in the Gazette not later than 14 days after the passing of the resolution or within such further period as the Chief Executive may allow in any particular case.

subsection.leadIn: An order made by the Chief Executive in Council under section 31 or 32 comes into operation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if on the expiry of the relevant period or that period as extended under subsection (3), (4) or (5), the Legislative Council has not passed a resolution amending the order, on the expiry of the relevant period or that period as so extended (as the case may be); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the Legislative Council passes a resolution amending the order, at the beginning of the day on which the resolution is published in the Gazette.

subsection.content: If an order is not laid on the table of the Legislative Council in accordance with this section, it is of no effect.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: sitting (會議), when used to calculate time, means the day on which the sitting commences and only includes a sitting at which subsidiary legislation is included on the order paper.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Register of decisions and block exemption orders

subsection.leadIn: The Commission must establish and maintain a register of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all decisions made in respect of applications made under section 9 or 24;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all notices of rescissions of such decisions, made under section 14 or 29;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: all block exemption orders issued under section 15; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: all orders varying or revoking block exemption orders, issued under section 20.

subsection.content: The Commission may omit confidential information from any entry made in the register under this section; and where confidential information has been omitted, that fact must be disclosed on the register.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission must make the register available for inspection by any person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at the offices of the Commission during ordinary business hours;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: through the Internet or a similar electronic network; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in any other manner the Commission considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission must issue guidelines—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: indicating the manner in which it expects to interpret and give effect to the conduct rules;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: regarding the manner and form in which it will receive applications for a decision or block exemption order; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: indicating how it expects to exercise its power to make a decision or grant block exemptions.

subsection.content: The Commission may amend any guidelines it issues under this section.
Guidelines issued under this section, and any amendments made to them, may be published in any manner the Commission considers appropriate.
Before issuing any guidelines or amendments to them under this section, the Commission must consult the Legislative Council and any persons it considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission must make available copies of all guidelines issued under this section and of all amendments made to them—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at the offices of the Commission during ordinary business hours;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: through the Internet or a similar electronic network; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in any other manner the Commission considers appropriate.

subsection.content: A person does not incur any civil or criminal liability only because the person has contravened any guidelines issued under this section or any amendments made to them.

subsection.leadIn: If, in any legal proceedings, the Tribunal or any other court is satisfied that a guideline is relevant to determining a matter that is in issue—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the guideline is admissible in evidence in the proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proof that a person contravened or did not contravene the guideline may be relied on by any party to the proceedings as tending to establish or negate the matter.

subsection.content: Guidelines issued under this section and all amendments made to them are not subsidiary legislation.
The Chief Executive in Council may by order amend Schedule 1.
An order made under subsection (1) is subject to the approval of the Legislative Council.

Any person may, in accordance with guidelines issued under section 38, lodge a complaint with the Commission alleging that an undertaking has contravened, is contravening or is about to contravene a competition rule.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission is not required to investigate a complaint if it does not consider it reasonable to do so and may, in particular, refuse to investigate a complaint if it is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the complaint is trivial, frivolous or vexatious; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the complaint is misconceived or lacking in substance.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Guidelines regarding complaints
section.content: The Commission must issue guidelines indicating the manner and form in which complaints are to be made.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may conduct an investigation into any conduct that constitutes or may constitute a contravention of a competition rule—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of its own volition;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where it has received a complaint under this Part;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where the Court of First Instance or the Tribunal has referred any conduct to it for investigation under section 118; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: where the Government has referred any conduct to it for investigation.

subsection.content: Despite subsection (1), the Commission may only conduct an investigation under this Part if it has reasonable cause to suspect that a contravention of a competition rule has taken place, is taking place or is about to take place.

section.name: s40
section.heading: Guidelines regarding investigations
section.leadIn: The Commission must issue guidelines indicating—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the procedures it will follow in deciding whether or not to conduct an investigation under this Part; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the procedures it will follow in conducting any investigation under this Part.

section.name: s41
section.heading: Powers to obtain documents and information

subsection.content: This section applies where the Commission has reasonable cause to suspect that a person has or may have possession or control of documents or information or may otherwise be able to assist it in relation to a matter that constitutes or may constitute a contravention of a competition rule.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of conducting an investigation, the Commission may by notice in writing require any person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to produce to it any document or a copy of any document; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to provide it with any specified information,

subsection.continued: relating to any matter it reasonably believes to be relevant to the investigation.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (2) must indicate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the subject matter and purpose of the investigation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the nature of the offences created by section 52 (Failure to comply with requirement or prohibition), section 53 (Destroying or falsifying documents) and section 55 (Providing false or misleading documents or information).

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may also specify in the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the time and place at which any document is to be produced or any information is to be provided; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the manner and form in which any document is to be produced or any information is to be provided.

subsection.leadIn: The power under this section to require a person to produce a document includes power—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the document is produced—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to make copies of it or to take extracts from it; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to require that person or any other person who is a present or past employee or partner of that person, or was at any time employed by that person, to give an explanation of or further particulars about the document;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the document is not produced, to require that person to state, to the best of the person’s knowledge and belief, where it is.

subsection.leadIn: The power under this section to require a person to provide specified information includes power—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to information recorded otherwise than in legible form, to require the production of a copy of the information in a visible and legible form or in a form from which it can readily be produced in a visible and legible form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to require the provision of instruction on the operation of equipment containing information stored electronically.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specified, or described, in the notice; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: falling within a category that is specified, or described, in the notice.

section.name: s42
section.heading: Persons may be required to attend before Commission

subsection.content: For the purpose of conducting an investigation, the Commission may, by notice in writing, require any person to attend before the Commission, at a time and place specified in the notice, to answer questions relating to any matter it reasonably believes to be relevant to the investigation.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (1) must indicate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the subject matter and purpose of the investigation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the nature of the offences created by section 52 (Failure to comply with requirement or prohibition), section 53 (Destroying or falsifying documents) and section 55 (Providing false or misleading documents or information).

subsection.content: The Commission may require a person giving any explanation, further particulars, answer or statement to the Commission under this Part to verify the truth of the explanation, particulars, answer or statement, by statutory declaration.
For the purpose of subsection (1) any member of the Commission may administer an oath or affirmation.

If a person fails to comply with a requirement made under this Part to give any explanation, further particulars, answer or statement to the Commission, the Commission may require that person to state, by statutory declaration, the reasons for the failure.

A person who gives evidence to the Commission under this Part and any counsel, solicitor, or other person who appears before the Commission under this Part has the same privileges and immunities as the person would have if the investigation were civil proceedings in the Court of First Instance.

In subsection (1), the reference to the giving of evidence includes a reference to producing any document, making any statement, giving any information, explanation or further particulars and answering any question.

subsection.leadIn: A person is not excused—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: from giving any explanation or further particulars about a document; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: from answering any question,

subsection.continued: under this Division on the grounds that to do so might expose the person to proceedings referred to in subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: No statement made by a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in giving any explanation or further particulars about a document; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in answering any question,

subsection.continued: under this Division is admissible against that person in proceedings referred to in subsection (3) unless, in the proceedings, evidence relating to the statement is adduced, or a question relating to it is asked, by that person or on that person’s behalf.

subsection.leadIn: The proceedings referred to in subsections (1) and (2) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: proceedings in which the Commission applies for an order for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a pecuniary penalty under section 93; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a financial penalty under section 169; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any criminal proceedings other than proceedings for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an offence under section 55 (Providing false or misleading documents or information);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an offence under Part V (Perjury) of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200); or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: an offence of perjury.

subsection.content: A person is not excused from providing to the Commission any information or producing any document to the Commission under this Part in respect of which an obligation of confidence is owed to any other person.

A person who, when required to do so under this Ordinance, produces any document or provides any information to the Commission, in respect of which an obligation of confidence is owed to any other person, is not personally liable for that act.

section.name: s47
section.heading: Appointment of authorized officers
section.content: The Commission may, in writing, appoint any employee of the Commission as an authorized officer of the Commission (an authorized officer) for the purposes of this Part.

section.name: s48
section.heading: Warrant to enter and search premises

subsection.content: A judge of the Court of First Instance may issue a warrant authorizing a person specified in the warrant, and any other persons who may be necessary to assist in the execution of the warrant, to enter and search any premises if the judge is satisfied, on application made on oath by an authorized officer, that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that there are or are likely to be, on the premises, documents that may be relevant to an investigation by the Commission.

A warrant under subsection (1) may be issued subject to any conditions specified in it that apply to the warrant itself or to any further authorization under it (whether granted under its terms or any provision of this Ordinance).

section.name: s49
section.heading: Duty to produce evidence of authority
section.leadIn: An authorized officer executing a warrant must, if requested, produce for inspection—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: documentary evidence of his or her identity;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: documentary evidence of his or her authorization under section 47; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the warrant.

subsection.leadIn: A warrant issued under section 48 authorizes the persons specified in it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to enter and search the premises specified in the warrant;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to use such force for gaining entry to the premises and for breaking open any article or thing found on the premises as is reasonable in the circumstances;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to make use of such equipment as is reasonable in the circumstances;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to remove by force any person or thing obstructing the execution of the warrant;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to require any person on the premises to produce any document that appears to be a relevant document, in the possession or under the control of that person;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to make copies of or take extracts from any document that appears to be a relevant document found on the premises or produced to a person executing the warrant;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: to prohibit any person found on the premises from—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: altering or otherwise interfering with any document that appears to be a relevant document; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: removing any such document from the premises or causing or permitting any other person to remove such document from the premises;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: to take possession of any documents found on the premises that appear to be relevant documents if—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: such action appears to be necessary for preserving the documents or preventing interference with them; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: it is not reasonably practicable to take copies of the documents on the premises;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: to take any other steps that appear to be necessary for the purpose mentioned in paragraph (h)(i);

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: to take possession of any computer or other thing found on the premises that the person executing the warrant has reasonable grounds for believing will, on examination, afford evidence of a contravention of a competition rule;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: to require any person on the premises to give an explanation of any document appearing to be a relevant document or to state, to the best of his or her knowledge and belief, where such an explanation may be found or obtained;

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.leadIn: to require any information which is stored in electronic form and is accessible from the premises and which the person executing the warrant considers relates to any matter relevant to the investigation, to be produced in a form—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in which it is visible and legible or from which it can readily be produced in a visible and legible form; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in which it can be taken away.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: relevant document (有關文件) means a document of a kind that could be required to be produced to the Commission under this Part.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: information (資料) includes information provided in answer to a question.

section.name: s52
section.heading: Failure to comply with requirement or prohibition

subsection.leadIn: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement or prohibition imposed on that person under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 41 (Powers to obtain documents and information);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 42 (Persons may be required to attend before Commission);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 43 (Statutory declaration regarding evidence); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: section 50 (Powers conferred by warrant),

subsection.continued: commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine of $200,000 and to imprisonment for 1 year; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if, having been required to produce a document under section 41 (Powers to obtain documents and information) or section 50 (Powers conferred by warrant), the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: intentionally or recklessly destroys or otherwise disposes of it, falsifies it or conceals it; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: causes or permits its destruction, disposal, falsification or concealment.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: It is an offence for a person to obstruct any person exercising a power under a warrant issued under section 48.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Providing false or misleading documents or information

subsection.leadIn: If any person produces or provides any document or information to the Commission under this Part, that person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the document or information is false or misleading in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person knows or is reckless as to whether the document or information is false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: A person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provides any document or information to another person, knowing the document or information to be false or misleading in a material particular; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: recklessly provides any document or information to another person that is false or misleading in a material particular,

subsection.continued: knowing that the document or information is to be used for the purpose of providing information to the Commission in connection with any of its functions under this Part, commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: If property is produced to the Commission in response to a requirement under this Part or is obtained under a warrant issued under section 48, the Commission may retain that property—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for as long as may be necessary for the purpose of its investigation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where it may be required for legal proceedings, for as long as may be necessary for the purpose of those proceedings.

subsection.content: If a document obtained under this Part is in the possession of the Commission, the Commission must, if requested by a person otherwise entitled to possession of the document, supply that person with a copy of the document certified by a member of the Commission to be a true copy of the original.

Until such a certified copy is issued, the Commission must, at any time and place it considers appropriate, allow a person otherwise entitled to possession of the document, or a person authorized by that person, to inspect and make copies of or take extracts from the document.
A certified copy of a document issued under this section is admissible in evidence in all courts as if it were the original.
If any property has come into possession of the Commission under this Ordinance, the Tribunal may order the disposal of the property in the manner provided in this section.

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal may, either of its own motion or on application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make an order for the delivery of the property to the person who appears to the Tribunal to be entitled to the property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person entitled to the property is unknown or cannot be found, make an order that the property be sold or retained in the possession of the Tribunal or the Commission; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the property is of no value, order that the property be destroyed.

subsection.content: An order for the delivery, sale or destruction of property must not, except where the property is perishable, be made under subsection (2) unless the Tribunal is satisfied that the property will not be required for the purpose of any proceedings before the Tribunal or any other court.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Tribunal orders the sale or retention of any property under subsection (2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no person establishes a claim to the property or the proceeds of sale of the property within 6 months after the day on which the order is made,

subsection.continued: the Tribunal may, either of its own motion or on application by the Commission, order that the property or the proceeds of sale become the property of the Government.

subsection.content: An order made under subsection (2), other than an order for the retention of property, must not, except where the property is perishable, be carried out until the period allowed for making an appeal against the order has expired or, where such an appeal is made, until the appeal is finally disposed of.

subsection.leadIn: An appeal is finally disposed of, for the purpose of subsection (5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if it is determined and the period for bringing any further appeal has ended; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if it is abandoned or otherwise ceases to have effect.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), this Part does not affect any claims, rights or entitlements that would, but for this Part, arise on the ground of legal professional privilege.
Subsection (1) does not affect any requirement under this Ordinance to disclose the name and address of a client of a counsel or solicitor.
The Commission may amend any guidelines it issues under this Part.
Guidelines issued under this Part, and any amendments made to them, may be published in any manner the Commission considers appropriate.
Before issuing any guidelines or amendments to them under this Part, the Commission must consult the Legislative Council and any persons it considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission must make available copies of all guidelines issued under this Part and of all amendments made to them—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at the offices of the Commission during ordinary business hours;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: through the Internet or a similar electronic network; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in any other manner the Commission considers appropriate.

subsection.content: A person does not incur any civil or criminal liability only because the person has contravened any guidelines issued under this Part or any amendments made to them.

subsection.leadIn: If, in any legal proceedings, the Tribunal or any other court is satisfied that a guideline is relevant to determining a matter that is in issue—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the guideline is admissible in evidence in the proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proof that a person contravened or did not contravene the guideline may be relied on by any party to the proceedings as tending to establish or negate the matter.

subsection.content: Guidelines issued under this Part and all amendments made to them are not subsidiary legislation.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may accept from a person a commitment to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: take any action; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refrain from taking any action,

subsection.continued: that the Commission considers appropriate to address its concerns about a possible contravention of a competition rule.

subsection.content: The action referred to in subsection (1)(a) does not include making a payment to the Government.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commission accepts a commitment under this section, it may agree—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not to commence an investigation or, if it has commenced an investigation, to terminate it; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not to bring proceedings in the Tribunal or, if it has brought proceedings, to terminate them.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commission accepts a commitment under this section, it may not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: commence or continue an investigation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: bring or continue proceedings in the Tribunal,

subsection.continued: in relation to any alleged contravention of a competition rule in so far as that investigation or those proceedings relate to matters that are addressed by the commitment.

subsection.leadIn: To avoid doubt, the Commission may still commence or continue an investigation or bring or continue proceedings in the Tribunal, after accepting a commitment under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to matters that are not addressed by the commitment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to persons who are not subject to the commitment.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commission decides to accept a commitment under this section, it must, as soon as practicable after accepting it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give notice in writing of that decision to the person who made the commitment, together with a copy of the commitment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: register the commitment on the register of commitments maintained under section 64 (Register of commitments).

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may, by notice in writing given to the person who made the commitment, withdraw its acceptance of a commitment, with effect from the date specified in the notice, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it has reasonable grounds for believing that there has been a material change of circumstances since the commitment was accepted;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it has reasonable grounds for suspecting that the person who made the commitment has failed to comply with the commitment; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: it has reasonable grounds for suspecting that the information on which it based its decision to accept the commitment was incomplete, false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commission is satisfied that any information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on which it based its decision to accept the commitment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which was provided to it by the person who made the commitment,

subsection.continued: was incomplete, false or misleading in a material particular, the date specified in the notice given under subsection (1) may be earlier than the date on which the notice is given.

subsection.leadIn: If an acceptance is withdrawn under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the commitment is no longer binding on the person who made it; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: subject to subsection (4), the Commission may—

subparagraph.content: commence an investigation; or
bring proceedings in the Tribunal,

paragraph.continued: with respect to any alleged contravention of the relevant competition rule that has occurred after the date specified in the notice given under subsection (1). (Amended 21 of 2020 s. 125)

subsection.content: The Commission may not bring proceedings authorized by subsection (3) more than 2 years after the date specified in the notice given under subsection (1).

section.name: s62
section.heading: Variation, substitution and release of commitment

subsection.leadIn: At any time after the Commission has accepted a commitment, it may accept from the person who has made it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a variation of the commitment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a new commitment in substitution for it,

subsection.continued: if it is satisfied that the variation or new commitment will address its concerns about a possible contravention of a competition rule.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may release any person from a commitment that the person has made under this Part if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is requested to do so by that person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it has reasonable grounds for believing that its concerns about the alleged contravention of the competition rule no longer arise.

subsection.content: If the Commission considers that a person has failed to comply with any commitment that the person has made under this Part (including a commitment to comply with the requirements of an infringement notice) and which has been accepted by the Commission, it may apply to the Tribunal for an order under subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: If the Tribunal is satisfied that a person has failed to comply with a commitment that the person has made under this Part and which has been accepted by the Commission, the Tribunal may make all or any of the following orders—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order directing the person to take such action or refrain from taking such action, as is specified in the commitment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order directing the person to pay to the Government an amount not exceeding the amount of any profit gained or loss avoided by that person as a result of the person’s failure to comply with the commitment;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an order directing the person to compensate any person for any loss or damage caused by the person’s failure to comply with the commitment; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other order that the Tribunal considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission must establish and maintain a register of commitments made under this Part (including commitments to comply with the requirements of an infringement notice) containing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of all commitments accepted under this Part (including any commitment accepted in substitution for another);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of all variations of commitments accepted under this Part;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where any acceptance of a commitment has been withdrawn, notice of that withdrawal; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: where any commitment has been released, notice of that release.

subsection.content: The Commission may omit confidential information from any entry made in the register under this section; and where confidential information has been omitted, that fact must be disclosed on the register.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission must make the register available for inspection by any person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at the offices of the Commission during ordinary business hours;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: through the Internet or a similar electronic network; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in any other manner the Commission considers appropriate.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Procedural requirements regarding commitments
section.leadIn: Schedule 2 has effect regarding the procedural requirements for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the acceptance of commitments;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the withdrawal of acceptance of commitments; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the variation and release of commitments,

section.name: s66
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: compliance period (遵守限期) means the period within which a person who has notified the Commission that the person proposes to comply with the requirements of an infringement notice must make a commitment to comply with the requirements of the notice;

notification period (通知限期) means the period (being a period of not more than 28 days) within which a person to whom an infringement notice has been issued must notify the Commission whether or not the person proposes to comply with the requirements of the notice.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) applies where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the Commission has reasonable cause to believe that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a contravention of the first conduct rule has occurred and the contravention involves serious anti-competitive conduct; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a contravention of the second conduct rule has occurred; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Commission has not yet brought proceedings in the Tribunal in respect of the contravention.

subsection.content: The Commission may, instead of bringing proceedings in the Tribunal in the first instance, issue a notice (an infringement notice) to the person against whom it proposes to bring proceedings, offering not to bring those proceedings on condition that the person makes a commitment to comply with requirements of the notice.

subsection.leadIn: The requirements of an infringement notice may include, but are not limited to, the following requirements—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to refrain from any specified conduct, or to take any specified action, that the Commission considers appropriate; and

paragraph.name: b
