paragraph.content: to admit to a contravention of the relevant conduct rule.

subsection.content: The action that may be specified by the Commission under subsection (3)(a) does not include making a payment to the Government.

section.name: s68
section.heading: Person not obliged to make commitment
section.content: A person is not obliged to make a commitment to comply with the requirements of an infringement notice, but if a person does not make the commitment within the compliance period, the Commission may bring proceedings against that person in the Tribunal in relation to the alleged contravention of the conduct rule.

section.name: s69
section.heading: Contents of infringement notice
section.leadIn: An infringement notice must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identify the conduct rule alleged to have been contravened;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: describe the conduct that is alleged to contravene that conduct rule;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: identify the person whose conduct is alleged to constitute the contravention;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: identify the evidence or other materials that the Commission relies on in support of its allegations;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: specify the requirements to be complied with by the person to whom the notice is addressed;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: specify both the notification period and the compliance period; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: be accompanied by a copy of section 68 (Person not obliged to make commitment).

section.name: s70
section.heading: Notice of proposal to issue infringement notice

subsection.leadIn: Before issuing an infringement notice to any person under section 67, the Commission must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give that person a notice under this section; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: consider any representations made in accordance with the notice.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under this section must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state that an infringement notice is proposed to be issued;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: contain a draft of the proposed infringement notice; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify a period, being a period of not less than 15 days, within which representations may be made as to why the infringement notice should not be issued.

subsection.leadIn: If a person makes a representation in response to a notice issued under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: evidence or information provided to the Commission in that representation may not be used against that person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no person may obtain discovery of that information or evidence against the Commission,

subsection.continued: in any proceedings, other than proceedings against that person for an offence under section 172 (Provision of false information).

section.name: s71
section.heading: Decision not to issue infringement notice
section.content: If after considering any representations made in response to a notice given under section 70, the Commission decides not to issue an infringement notice, it must give notice of that decision to the person to whom the notice under section 70 was given.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Effect of issue of infringement notice

subsection.leadIn: If an infringement notice has been issued to any person, no proceedings may be brought by the Commission against that person in respect of the contravention referred to in the notice if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the compliance period has not expired; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the infringement notice has not been withdrawn.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may not publish an infringement notice (or disclose the whole or any part of its contents)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: before the expiry of its compliance period;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a commitment to comply with the requirements of the notice is not made within the compliance period; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the Commission has withdrawn the notice.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Withdrawal of infringement notice
section.content: The Commission may at any time before the expiry of the compliance period, by notice in writing given to a person to whom an infringement notice has been issued, withdraw the infringement notice with effect from a date specified in the notice.

subsection.content: The Commission may, either of its own volition or on application made to it in writing, extend the compliance period specified in an infringement notice if it considers that there is a good reason for doing so.
An application for an extension under subsection (1) must be made before the expiry of the period sought to be extended.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Effect of commitment to comply with requirements of infringement notice
section.content: If a person makes a commitment to comply with the requirements of an infringement notice within the compliance period, the Commission may not bring proceedings in the Tribunal against that person in respect of the alleged contravention specified in the notice.

section.name: s76
section.heading: Failure to comply with requirements of infringement notice

subsection.content: This section applies where a person has made a commitment to the Commission to comply with the requirements of an infringement notice.

Nothing in section 75 prevents the Commission from bringing proceedings in the Tribunal, where it has reasonable grounds for suspecting that the person who has made the commitment has failed to comply with one or more of the requirements of the infringement notice.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Registration of commitments
section.content: The Commission must register commitments made under this Division in the register maintained by the Commission under section 64 (Register of commitments) and the provisions of that section also apply, with any necessary modifications that the circumstances require, to commitments made under this Division.

section.name: s78
section.heading: Publication of infringement notices
section.leadIn: If a person has made a commitment under this Division to comply with the requirements of an infringement notice, the Commission may publish the infringement notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: through the Internet or a similar electronic network; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other manner the Commission considers appropriate.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a corporation, a director, manager or company secretary of the corporation, and any other person involved in the management of the corporation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to an undertaking (other than a corporation or partnership), any member of the governing body of that undertaking.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may, in exchange for a person’s co-operation in an investigation or in proceedings under this Ordinance, make an agreement (a leniency agreement) with the person, on any terms it considers appropriate, that it will not bring or continue proceedings under Part 6 for a pecuniary penalty in respect of an alleged contravention of a conduct rule against—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person is a natural person, that person or any employee or agent of that person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person is a corporation, that corporation or any officer, employee or agent of the corporation;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: if the person is an undertaking other than one referred to in paragraph (a), (b) or (c), that undertaking or any officer, employee or agent of the undertaking,

subsection.continued: in so far as the contravention consists of the conduct specified in the agreement.

subsection.content: The Commission must not, while a leniency agreement is in force, bring or continue proceedings under Part 6 for a pecuniary penalty in breach of that leniency agreement.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may terminate a leniency agreement if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the other party to the agreement agrees to the termination;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it has reasonable grounds to suspect that the information on which it based its decision to make the agreement was incomplete, false or misleading in a material particular;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the other party to the agreement, or if the agreement was made by a person as an officer, employee or agent of an undertaking, that undertaking has been convicted of an offence under Part 3; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: it is satisfied that the other party to the agreement, or if the agreement was made by a person as an officer, employee or agent of an undertaking, that undertaking has failed to comply with the terms of the agreement.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may terminate a leniency agreement by giving notice in writing to the other party to the agreement and to any other person who appears to the Commission to be likely to benefit from the agreement, stating—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the termination; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reasons for the termination.

subsection.content: A notice under subsection (2) must specify the period within which representations may be made to the Commission about the proposed termination.
The period specified for the purpose of subsection (3) must be a period of at least 30 days beginning after the day on which the notice is given.
Before terminating a leniency agreement, the Commission must consider any representations about the proposed termination that are made to it.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commission has reasonable cause to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a contravention of the first conduct rule has occurred; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contravention does not involve serious anti-competitive conduct,

subsection.continued: the Commission must, before bringing proceedings in the Tribunal against the undertaking whose conduct is alleged to constitute the contravention, issue a notice (a warning notice) to the undertaking.

subsection.leadIn: A warning notice must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: describe the conduct (the contravening conduct) that is alleged to constitute the contravention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: identify the undertaking (the contravening undertaking) that has engaged in the contravening conduct;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: identify the evidence or other materials that the Commission relies on in support of its allegations;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: state—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the Commission requires the contravening undertaking to cease the contravening conduct within the period (the warning period) specified in the notice, and not to repeat that conduct after the warning period;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that, if the contravening conduct continues after the expiry of the warning period, the Commission may bring proceedings in the Tribunal against the contravening undertaking in respect of the contravening conduct; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: that, if the contravening undertaking repeats the contravening conduct after the expiry of the warning period, the Commission may bring proceedings in the Tribunal against the contravening undertaking in respect of the contravening conduct and the repeated conduct; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: indicate the manner in which the contravening undertaking may cease the contravening conduct.

subsection.content: In determining the warning period, the Commission must have regard to the amount of time which the contravening undertaking is likely to require to cease the contravening conduct.

subsection.leadIn: After the expiry of the warning period—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the Commission has reasonable cause to believe that the contravening conduct continues after the expiry, the Commission may bring proceedings in the Tribunal against the contravening undertaking in respect of the contravening conduct; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the Commission has reasonable cause to believe that the contravening undertaking repeats the contravening conduct after the expiry, the Commission may bring proceedings in the Tribunal against the contravening undertaking in respect of the contravening conduct and the repeated conduct.

subsection.content: To avoid doubt, proceedings under subsection (4) may not be brought in respect of any period that precedes the warning period.

The Commission may, either of its own volition or on application made to it in writing, extend the warning period specified in a warning notice if it considers that there is a good reason for doing so.
An application for an extension under subsection (6) must be made before the expiry of the period sought to be extended.

section.name: s83
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a decision regarding an agreement, made by the Commission under section 11;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a rescission of a decision regarding an agreement, made by the Commission under section 14;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a decision relating to the issue of a block exemption order, made by the Commission under section 15;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a decision relating to the variation or revocation of a block exemption order, made by the Commission under section 20;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a decision regarding specific conduct, made by the Commission under section 26;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a rescission of a decision regarding specific conduct, made by the Commission under section 29;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a decision relating to the variation of a commitment, made by the Commission under section 62;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: a decision relating to the release of a person from a commitment, made by the Commission under section 62;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: a decision relating to the termination of a leniency agreement, made by the Commission under section 81;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: a decision regarding a merger or proposed merger, made by the Commission under section 13 of Schedule 7; or

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: a rescission of a decision regarding a merger or proposed merger, made by the Commission under section 15 of Schedule 7.

subsection.content: An application may be made to the Tribunal by any person or undertaking specified or referred to in section 85 for a review of a reviewable determination.
An application under subsection (1) may only be made with the leave of the Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: Leave may not be granted under subsection (2) unless the Tribunal is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the review has a reasonable prospect of success; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is some other reason in the interests of justice why the review should be heard.

subsection.leadIn: An application for a review under this Part may be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a decision or a rescission of a decision, by the undertaking that applied for the decision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a decision relating to the variation of a commitment or the release of a person from a commitment, by the person who made the commitment; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a decision relating to the termination of a leniency agreement, by a party to the agreement.

subsection.content: A person who does not fall under subsection (1) may also apply to the Tribunal for a review of a reviewable determination, other than a decision regarding a merger or proposed merger, if the Tribunal is satisfied that the person has a sufficient interest in the reviewable determination.

section.name: s86
section.heading: Tribunal may state case for Court of Appeal

subsection.content: Before or after the determination of an application for review made under section 84, the Tribunal may, either of its own motion or on application, refer any question of law arising in, or that has arisen in, the review to the Court of Appeal for determination by way of case stated.

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal may only refer a question of law to the Court of Appeal under subsection (1) if it is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the party who has applied for the question of law to be referred has a reasonable prospect of success; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that there is some other reason in the interests of justice why the question of law should be referred.

subsection.leadIn: On the hearing of the case, the Court of Appeal may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: determine the question stated;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: amend the case or require the Tribunal to amend the case in any manner the Court specifies; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: remit the case to the Tribunal for reconsideration in the light of the decision of the Court.

section.name: s87
section.heading: Decision of Tribunal on application for review
section.leadIn: In determining an application for a review, the Tribunal may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: confirm or set aside the whole or part of the determination to which it relates; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where it sets aside the whole or part of a determination, refer the matter back to the Commission with a direction to reconsider and make a new determination in accordance with the decision of the Tribunal.

section.name: s88
section.heading: Time limit for applying for review

subsection.content: An application for the review of a reviewable determination must be made within 30 days after the day on which the determination was made.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1), the Tribunal may extend the time referred to in that subsection if it is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is a good reason for doing so; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no injustice would be caused as a result of the extension.

subsection.content: Despite subsection (2), an application for a review of a reviewable determination may not be made more than 3 years after the day on which the determination was made.

section.name: s89
section.heading: Stay of execution of reviewable determination

subsection.content: The making of an application for review does not by itself operate as a stay of execution of the determination to which the application relates.

A person or undertaking that has made an application for review may, at any time before the application is determined by the Tribunal, apply to the Tribunal for a stay of execution of the determination to which the application relates.

When an application is made under subsection (2), the Tribunal must, as soon as reasonably practicable, conduct a hearing to determine the application, and may, where it considers it appropriate, order a stay of execution of the determination to which the application relates.
An order for a stay of execution under this section may be made subject to such conditions as to costs, payment of money into the Tribunal or otherwise as the Tribunal considers appropriate.

section.name: s90
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: disqualification order (取消資格令) means an order made by the Tribunal under section 101 disqualifying a person from being a director of a company or from otherwise being concerned in the affairs of a company;
pecuniary penalty (罰款) means a pecuniary penalty ordered to be paid, under section 93.

section.name: s91
section.heading: Persons involved in contravention of competition rule
section.leadIn: A reference in this Part to a person being involved in a contravention of a competition rule means a person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: attempts to contravene the rule;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: aids, abets, counsels or procures any other person to contravene the rule;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: induces or attempts to induce any other person, whether by threats or promises or otherwise, to contravene the rule;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: is in any way, directly or indirectly, knowingly concerned in or a party to the contravention of the rule; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: conspires with any other person to contravene the rule.

section.name: s92
section.heading: Commission may apply for pecuniary penalty

subsection.leadIn: If, after carrying out such investigation as it considers appropriate, the Commission considers it appropriate to do so, it may apply to the Tribunal for a pecuniary penalty to be imposed on any person it has reasonable cause to believe—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has contravened a competition rule; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been involved in a contravention of a competition rule.

subsection.leadIn: An application under subsection (1) may not be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an application with respect to a contravention of the merger rule, more than 6 months after the day on which the merger was completed or the Commission became aware of the merger, whichever is the later; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of an application with respect to a contravention of a conduct rule, more than 5 years after the day on which the contravention ceased or the Commission became aware of the contravention, whichever is the later.

subsection.content: If the Tribunal is satisfied, on application by the Commission under section 92, that a person has contravened or been involved in a contravention of a competition rule, it may order that person to pay to the Government a pecuniary penalty of any amount it considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the matters that the Tribunal may have regard to, in determining the amount of the pecuniary penalty, the Tribunal must have regard to the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the nature and extent of the conduct that constitutes the contravention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the loss or damage, if any, caused by the conduct;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the circumstance in which the conduct took place; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: whether the person has previously been found by the Tribunal to have contravened this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The amount of a pecuniary penalty imposed under subsection (1) in relation to conduct that constitutes a single contravention may not exceed in total—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), 10% of the turnover of the undertaking concerned for each year in which the contravention occurred; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the contravention occurred in more than 3 years, 10% of the turnover of the undertaking concerned for the 3 years in which the contravention occurred that saw the highest, second highest and third highest turnover.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: year (年度) means the financial year of an undertaking or, if the undertaking does not have a financial year, a calendar year.

subsection.content: If the Tribunal is satisfied that a person has contravened, or been involved in a contravention of a competition rule, it may (whether or not it makes an order under section 93 imposing a pecuniary penalty), either of its own motion or on application made for this purpose, make any order it considers appropriate against that person, including all or any of the orders specified in Schedule 3.

subsection.leadIn: An application for an order under subsection (1) may not be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an application with respect to a contravention of the merger rule, more than 6 months after the day on which the merger was completed or the Commission became aware of the merger, whichever is the later; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of an application with respect to a contravention of a conduct rule, more than 5 years after the day on which the contravention ceased or the Commission became aware of the contravention, whichever is the later.

subsection.content: Despite subsection (2)(a), the Tribunal may, on application made before the expiry of the period referred to in that subsection, extend the period within which an application under subsection (1) may be made with respect to a contravention of the merger rule if the Tribunal considers it reasonable to do so.

Subject to subsection (2), if the Tribunal is satisfied that a person is engaged in or is proposing to engage in conduct that constitutes or would constitute a contravention of the competition rules, it may, either of its own motion or on application made for this purpose, make an interim order pending its determination of an application for an order under section 94.

A person other than the Commission is not entitled to make an application under subsection (1) by reason that any other person is engaged in or is proposing to engage in conduct that contravenes or would contravene the merger rule.

An interim order remains in force for the period, being a period of not more than 180 days, specified in the order, but this period may be extended by the Tribunal for a further period of not more than 180 days on any one occasion.
An interim order may be made whether or not an application for a pecuniary penalty under section 92 or an order under section 94 has been made.

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal may make an order under this section whether or not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person against whom the order is to be made intends to engage again in or intends to continue to engage in the conduct that is to be the subject of the order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person against whom the order is to be made has previously engaged in the conduct that is to be the subject of the order; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: there is an imminent danger of damage or loss being incurred by any person if the order is not made.

section.name: s96
section.heading: Order to pay costs of Commission investigation

subsection.content: The Tribunal may order any person who has contravened a competition rule to pay to the Government an amount equal to the amount of the costs of and incidental to any investigation into the conduct or affairs of that person, reasonably incurred by the Commission in connection with proceedings for the contravention.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: costs (開支) include fees, charges, disbursements, expenses and remuneration.

section.name: s97
section.heading: Proceedings in relation to anticipated mergers

subsection.content: If the Commission, after conducting an investigation, has reasonable cause to believe that arrangements are in progress or in contemplation which, if carried into effect, will result in a merger that is likely to contravene the merger rule, it may apply to the Tribunal for an order under this section.

subsection.leadIn: If the Tribunal is satisfied, on application made under this section, that arrangements are in progress or in contemplation which, if carried into effect, will result in a merger that is likely to contravene the merger rule, it may make an order directed against a party to the arrangements or any other person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ordering the person against whom the order is directed not to proceed with the merger;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ordering the person against whom the order is directed not to proceed with a part of the merger;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in addition to or instead of an order referred to in paragraph (b), prohibiting the person against whom the order is directed from doing anything that will result in a merger.

subsection.content: If the Tribunal is not satisfied that an arrangement, if carried into effect, will result in a merger that is likely to contravene the merger rule, it may make a declaration to that effect.
An order under this section may contain anything permitted by Schedule 4.

subsection.leadIn: If an application has been made to the Tribunal under section 97 but has not yet been finally determined, the Tribunal may, either of its own motion or on application by the Commission, make interim orders for the purpose of preventing pre-emptive action, including orders—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prohibiting or restricting the doing of things that the Tribunal considers would constitute pre-emptive action;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: imposing on any person concerned obligations as to the carrying on of any activities or the safeguarding of any assets;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: providing for the carrying on of any activities or the safeguarding of any assets either by the appointment of a person to conduct or supervise the conduct of any activities (on any terms and with any powers that may be specified or described in the order) or in any other manner.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: pre-emptive action (先發制人行動) means any action that might prejudice the hearing of the application under section 97 or any final order that the Tribunal might make on the hearing of the application.

subsection.content: If the Commission, after carrying out such investigation as it considers appropriate, has reasonable cause to believe that a merger contravenes the merger rule, it may apply to the Tribunal for an order under section 100.

An application for an order under subsection (1) must be made within the period of 6 months after the day on which the merger was completed or the Commission became aware of the merger, whichever is the later.

Despite subsection (2), the Tribunal may, on application by the Commission made before the expiry of the period referred to in that subsection, extend the period within which an application under subsection (1) may be made if the Tribunal considers it reasonable to do so.

If the Tribunal is satisfied, on application by the Commission under section 99, that a merger contravenes the merger rule, it may make any order it considers appropriate for the purpose of bringing the contravention to an end.
An order made under subsection (1) may contain anything permitted by Schedule 4.
In the circumstances specified in section 102, the Tribunal may, on application by the Commission, make a disqualification order against a person.

subsection.leadIn: A disqualification order is an order that a person may not, without the leave of the Tribunal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be, or continue to be, a director of a company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be a liquidator or provisional liquidator of a company;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be a receiver or manager of a company’s property; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in any way, whether directly or indirectly, be concerned or take part in the promotion, formation or management of a company,

subsection.continued: for a specified period, not exceeding 5 years, beginning with the date of the order.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: specified (指明) means specified in the disqualification order.

section.name: s102
section.heading: Circumstances in which disqualification order may be made
section.leadIn: The Tribunal may only make a disqualification order against a person if both of the following conditions are satisfied in relation to that person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it has determined that a company of which the person is a director has contravened a competition rule; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it considers that the person’s conduct as a director makes the person unfit to be concerned in the management of a company.

section.name: s103
section.heading: Unfitness to be concerned in management of company

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of deciding under section 102(b) whether a person is unfit to be concerned in the management of a company, the Tribunal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must have regard to whether subsection (2) applies to the person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may have regard to the conduct of the person as the director of a company, in connection with any other contravention of a competition rule.

subsection.leadIn: This subsection applies to a person if as a director of the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s conduct contributed to the contravention of the competition rule;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the conduct of the person did not contribute to the contravention, but the person had reasonable grounds to suspect that the conduct of the company constituted the contravention and took no steps to prevent it; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person did not know but ought to have known that the conduct of the company constituted the contravention.

section.name: s104
section.heading: Applications for disqualification order and for leave under an order

subsection.content: An application for a disqualification order may be made only by the Commission.

An application for leave of the Tribunal to participate in the affairs of a company in one of the ways prohibited under section 101(2) (Disqualification order) may be made only by or on behalf of the person against whom the order was made.

section.name: s105
section.heading: Contravention of disqualification order
section.leadIn: A person who contravenes a disqualification order commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: follow-on action (後續訴訟) means an action brought by a person who has a right to bring the action under section 110(1).

section.name: s107
section.heading: Persons involved in contravention of conduct rule
section.leadIn: A reference in this Part to a person being involved in a contravention of a conduct rule means a person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: attempts to contravene the rule;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: aids, abets, counsels or procures any other person to contravene the rule;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: induces or attempts to induce any other person, whether by threats or promises or otherwise, to contravene the rule;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: is in any way, directly or indirectly, knowingly concerned in or a party to the contravention of the rule; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: conspires with any person to contravene the rule.

section.name: s108
section.heading: No proceedings independent of this Ordinance
section.leadIn: No person may bring any proceedings independently of this Ordinance, whether under any rule of law or any enactment, in any court in Hong Kong, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the cause of action is the defendant’s contravention, or involvement in a contravention, of a conduct rule; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the proceedings are founded on more than one cause of action and any of the causes of action is the defendant’s contravention, or involvement in a contravention, of a conduct rule.

section.name: s109
section.heading: Pure competition proceedings not to be brought in Court of First Instance
section.content: No person may bring any proceedings in the Court of First Instance under this Part if the cause of action is only the defendant’s contravention, or involvement in a contravention, of a conduct rule.

subsection.leadIn: A person who has suffered loss or damage as a result of any act that has been determined to be a contravention of a conduct rule has a right of action under this section against—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any person who has contravened or is contravening the rule; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person who is, or has been, involved in that contravention.

subsection.content: Subject to section 113, a claim to which this section applies may only be made in proceedings brought in the Tribunal, whether or not the cause of action is solely the defendant’s contravention, or involvement in a contravention, of a conduct rule.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of subsection (1), an act is taken to have been determined to be a contravention of a conduct rule if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Tribunal has made a decision that the act is a contravention of a conduct rule;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court of First Instance has decided, in any proceedings transferred to it by the Tribunal under section 114(3), that the act is a contravention of a conduct rule;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Court of Appeal has decided, on an appeal from a decision of the Tribunal or the Court of First Instance, that the act is a contravention of a conduct rule;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Court of Final Appeal has decided, on an appeal from a decision of the Court of Appeal, that the act is a contravention of a conduct rule; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a person has made an admission, in a commitment that has been accepted by the Commission, that the person has contravened a conduct rule.

subsection.leadIn: The periods during which proceedings for a follow-on action may not be brought are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a decision of the Tribunal, the period during which an appeal may be made to the Court of Appeal under section 154;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a decision of the Court of First Instance, the period during which an appeal may be made to the Court of Appeal; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a decision of the Court of Appeal, the period during which a further appeal may be made to the Court of Final Appeal,

subsection.continued: and, where any such appeal or further appeal is made, the period specified in paragraph (a), (b) or (c) includes the period before the appeal is determined.

subsection.content: Despite subsection (1), the Court of First Instance or the Tribunal may, on the application of the party seeking to bring the proceedings, permit proceedings for a follow-on action to be brought within any period specified in subsection (1).

Proceedings for a follow-on action may not be brought more than 3 years after the earliest date on which the action could have been commenced following the expiry of a relevant period specified in subsection (1).

section.name: s112
section.heading: Tribunal orders in follow-on actions
section.content: The Tribunal in a follow-on action may make any one or more of the orders specified in Schedule 3.

section.name: s113
section.heading: Transfer of proceedings from Court of First Instance to Tribunal

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), the Court of First Instance must transfer to the Tribunal so much of the proceedings before the Court that are within the jurisdiction of the Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply to any proceedings that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: are within the jurisdiction of the Tribunal under section 142(1)(g); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court of First Instance considers should not, in the interests of justice, be transferred to the Tribunal.

subsection.content: Without limiting subsection (1) but subject to section 115(2), if, in any proceedings before the Court of First Instance, a contravention, or involvement in a contravention, of a conduct rule is alleged as a defence, the Court must, in respect of the allegation, transfer to the Tribunal so much of those proceedings that are within the jurisdiction of the Tribunal.
The practice and procedure of the Tribunal apply to the proceedings transferred by the Court of First Instance under subsection (1) or (3).

section.name: s114
section.heading: Transfer of proceedings from Tribunal to Court of First Instance

subsection.content: The Tribunal must transfer to the Court of First Instance so much of the proceedings brought in the Tribunal that are within the jurisdiction of the Court but are not within the jurisdiction of the Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (1), the Tribunal may transfer to the Court of First Instance any proceedings brought in the Tribunal but only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: those proceedings are within the jurisdiction of the Tribunal under section 142(1)(g); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Tribunal considers that those proceedings should, in the interests of justice, be transferred to the Court.

subsection.content: If the Court of First Instance transfers any proceedings to the Tribunal under section 113(3), the Tribunal may transfer back to the Court so much of those proceedings that the Tribunal considers should, in the interests of justice, be transferred back to the Court.
The practice and procedure of the Court of First Instance apply to the proceedings transferred by the Tribunal under subsection (1), (2) or (3).

section.name: s115
section.heading: No further transfer of proceedings from Court of First Instance to Tribunal

subsection.content: If the Tribunal transfers any proceedings to the Court of First Instance under section 114(2), the Court must not transfer back those proceedings to the Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: If the Tribunal transfers any proceedings to the Court of First Instance under section 114(3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 113(3) does not apply to those proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court must not transfer back those proceedings to the Tribunal.

section.name: s116
section.heading: No further transfer of proceedings from Tribunal to Court of First Instance
section.content: If the Court of First Instance transfers any proceedings to the Tribunal under section 113(1), the Tribunal must not transfer back those proceedings to the Court.

subsection.content: If the Court of First Instance makes an order transferring proceedings to the Tribunal under section 113, it may make an order for costs prior to the transfer and of the transfer.
If the Tribunal makes an order transferring proceedings to the Court of First Instance under section 114, it may make an order for costs prior to the transfer and of the transfer.

section.name: s118
section.heading: Reference by Court of First Instance or Tribunal to Commission for investigation

subsection.content: In any proceedings before the Court of First Instance or the Tribunal in which a contravention, or involvement in a contravention, of a conduct rule is alleged, the Court or the Tribunal may, either of its own motion or on application by a party to the proceedings, refer the alleged contravention or alleged involvement to the Commission for investigation under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court of First Instance or the Tribunal has referred an alleged contravention, or alleged involvement in a contravention, of a conduct rule to the Commission for investigation, it may stay the proceedings before it pending—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a referral by the Tribunal, the completion of the Commission’s investigation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a referral by the Court, the completion of the Commission’s investigation and any subsequent proceedings in the Tribunal brought as a result of the investigation.

section.name: s119
section.heading: Findings of contravention of conduct rules

subsection.content: This section applies to proceedings under this Part before the Court of First Instance or the Tribunal in which a contravention, or involvement in a contravention, of a conduct rule is alleged in relation to a particular act.

Subject to subsection (3), in such proceedings the Court of First Instance or the Tribunal (as the case requires) is bound by an earlier decision of the Court or Tribunal that the act in question is a contravention, or involvement in a contravention, of the conduct rule.
Subsection (2) does not apply in relation to a decision of the Court of First Instance or the Tribunal until the period specified in subsection (4) has expired.

subsection.leadIn: The period mentioned in subsection (3) is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the period during which an appeal may be made to the Court of Appeal under section 154; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where an appeal has been made to the Court of Appeal, the period during which a further appeal may be made to the Court of Final Appeal,

subsection.continued: and, where such an appeal or further appeal is made, the period specified in paragraph (a) or (b) includes the period before the appeal is determined.

subsection.content: This section applies to proceedings involving an alleged contravention, or alleged involvement in a contravention, of a conduct rule, before the specified Court or the Tribunal, that are brought by a person other than the Commission.
The Commission may, with the leave of the specified Court or the Tribunal, and subject to any conditions imposed by the specified Court or the Tribunal, intervene in any such proceedings.
An application for leave under this section must be made in the prescribed form and must be served by the Commission on each party to the proceedings.

If the Commission intervenes in proceedings under this section, the Commission becomes, as from the date of the grant of leave, a party to the proceedings and has all the rights, duties and liabilities of a party to the proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Court of Final Appeal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court of Appeal; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Court of First Instance.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may, with the leave of or at the invitation of the specified Court or the Tribunal (as the case requires), participate in proceedings before the specified Court or the Tribunal involving an alleged contravention, or alleged involvement in a contravention, of a conduct rule that have been brought by another person and, in particular may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make written submissions to the specified Court or the Tribunal; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: apply for, or join an application for, the adjournment of the proceedings pending the completion of the Commission’s investigation into the alleged contravention or involvement that is in issue in the proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Court of Final Appeal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court of Appeal; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Court of First Instance.

section.name: s122
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commission;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person who is or was a member, employee or agent of the Commission;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any person who is or was a member of a committee of the Commission, established under section 28 of Schedule 5;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Communications Authority;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any person who is or was a member of the Communications Authority;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: any person who is or was a member of a committee of the Communications Authority, appointed under section 17 of the Communications Authority Ordinance (Cap. 616);

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: any person who is or was a public officer serving in the Office of the Communications Authority;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: any person who is or was an employee or agent of the Office of the Communications Authority; or

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: any person appointed to assist any person referred to in paragraphs (a), (b), (c), (d), (e), (f), (g) and (h) in the exercise of the powers of the Commission under Part 3.

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: information that has been provided to or obtained by the Commission in the course of, or in connection with, the performance of its functions under this Ordinance, that relates to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the private affairs of a natural person;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the commercial activities of any person that are of a confidential nature; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the identity of any person who has given information to the Commission;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: information that has been given to the Commission on terms that or in circumstances that require it to be held in confidence; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: information given to the Commission that has been identified as confidential information in accordance with subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: If a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identifies information that the person has given to the Commission as confidential; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provides a statement in writing setting out the reasons why, in that person’s opinion, the information is confidential,

subsection.continued: the information is also to be regarded as confidential information under this Part.

section.name: s124
section.heading: Duty to establish and maintain safeguards

subsection.content: The Commission and the Communications Authority must establish and maintain adequate procedural safeguards to prevent the unauthorized disclosure of confidential information.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: unauthorized disclosure (在未經授權下披露) means disclosure that is either prohibited or not authorized by or under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: A specified person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must preserve and aid in preserving the confidentiality of any confidential information;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must not disclose confidential information to any other person; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must not suffer or permit any other person to have access to confidential information.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply to the disclosure of confidential information with lawful authority within the meaning of section 126.

subsection.leadIn: A specified person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under this section to show that at the time of the alleged offence the defendant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: believed that there was lawful authority for the disclosure of the information concerned and the defendant had no reasonable cause to believe otherwise; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: did not know and had no reasonable cause to believe that the information disclosed was confidential information.

subsection.leadIn: Disclosure of confidential information is to be regarded as made with lawful authority if the disclosure is made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to section 127, with the required consent, as specified in subsection (2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (3), in the performance of any function of the Commission or in carrying into effect or doing anything authorized by this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in accordance with an order of the Tribunal or any other court or in accordance with a law or a requirement made by or under a law;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in connection with judicial proceedings arising under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: for the purpose of obtaining advice from counsel, a solicitor or other professional adviser acting or proposing to act in a professional capacity in connection with any matter arising under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: with a view to the bringing of, or otherwise for the purposes of, any criminal proceedings, or any investigation carried out under the laws of Hong Kong, in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: with respect to information that has already been lawfully disclosed to the public on an earlier occasion; or

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: by one competition authority to another.

subsection.leadIn: The consent required for the purposes of subsection (1)(a) is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the information was obtained from a person who had the information lawfully and the Commission knows the identity of that person, the consent of that person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the information relates to the affairs of a natural person, the consent of that person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the information relates to the activities of an undertaking, the consent of that undertaking, and that consent may be given—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: if the undertaking is a company, by a director or company secretary of the company;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the undertaking is a partnership, by a partner; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if the undertaking is an unincorporated body (other than a partnership), by a person concerned in the management or control of the body.

subsection.leadIn: In deciding whether or not to disclose confidential information, where disclosure is lawful under subsection (1)(b), the specified person must consider and have regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the need to exclude as far as is practical, from such disclosure—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: information the disclosure of which would, in the opinion of the specified person, be contrary to public interest;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: commercial information the disclosure of which would or might be likely to, in the opinion of the specified person, significantly harm the legitimate business interests of the person to whom it relates; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: information relating to the private affairs of a natural person, the disclosure of which might (in the opinion of the specified person) significantly harm the interest of that person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the extent to which the disclosure is necessary for the purpose sought to be achieved by the disclosure.

subsection.leadIn: If the disclosure of confidential information is lawful by virtue of section 126(1)(a), a specified person must, before disclosing any such information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: give notice of the proposed disclosure to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the person who provided the information to the Commission; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any person who is, in the opinion of the specified person, likely to be affected by the disclosure; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: consider any representations that are made about the proposed disclosure.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (1) must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give a description of the information (having due regard to the requirements of confidentiality) that the specified person proposes to disclose;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: state the reasons why the disclosure is proposed;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: identify the person to whom it is proposed to disclose the information; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: state any other facts that the specified person considers relevant to the question of the proposed disclosure.

subsection.content: A notice under this section must specify the period within which representations may be made about the proposed disclosure.
The period specified for the purpose of subsection (3) must be a period of at least 30 days beginning after the day on which the notice is given.

section.name: s128
section.heading: Obligation of third party not to disclose confidential information

subsection.leadIn: A person, other than a specified person, who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has received confidential information from the Commission; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has otherwise, directly or indirectly, received such information from a specified person,

subsection.continued: must not disclose that information to any other person or suffer or permit any other person to have access to that information.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply to the disclosure of information where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commission has consented to the disclosure;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the information has already been lawfully disclosed to the public on an earlier occasion;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the disclosure is for the purpose of obtaining advice from counsel, a solicitor or other professional adviser, acting or proposing to act in a professional capacity in connection with any matter arising under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the disclosure is made in connection with any judicial proceedings arising under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the disclosure is made in accordance with an order of the Tribunal or any other court or in accordance with a law or a requirement made by or under a law.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: There is established, by virtue of this section, a body to be known as the “Competition Commission”. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

subsection.leadIn: The Commission is a body corporate and may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: acquire, hold and dispose of movable and immovable property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sue and be sued in its own name; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: so far as is possible for a body corporate, exercise all the rights and powers, enjoy all the privileges and incur all the liabilities of a natural person of full age and capacity.

subsection.content: Schedule 5 (which contains constitutional, administrative and financial provisions) has effect with respect to the Commission.

section.name: s130
section.heading: Functions of Commission
section.leadIn: The Commission has the following functions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to investigate conduct that may contravene the competition rules and enforce the provisions of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to promote public understanding of the value of competition and how this Ordinance promotes competition;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to promote the adoption by undertakings carrying on business in Hong Kong of appropriate internal controls and risk management systems, to ensure their compliance with this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to advise the Government on competition matters in Hong Kong and outside Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to conduct market studies into matters affecting competition in markets in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to promote research into and the development of skills in relation to the legal, economic and policy aspects of competition law in Hong Kong.

subsection.content: The Commission may do all such things as appear to it to be necessary, advantageous or expedient for it to do for, or in connection with, the performance of its functions.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the scope of subsection (1), the Commission may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make, give effect to, assign or accept the assignment of, vary or rescind any agreement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: receive and spend money;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: with the approval of the Financial Secretary, borrow money;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: invest funds of the Commission that are not immediately required, in a manner approved by the Financial Secretary;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: with the approval of the Chief Executive, become a member or affiliate of any international body, whose functions or objects include the promotion of competition or competition law.

section.name: s132
section.heading: Commission not servant or agent of Government
section.content: The Commission is not a servant or agent of the Government and does not enjoy any status, immunity or privilege of the Government.

section.name: s133
section.heading: Personal immunity of members of Commission etc.

subsection.content: A person to whom this subsection applies is not personally liable for anything done or omitted to be done by the person in good faith in the performance or purported performance of any function of the Commission under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The persons to whom subsection (1) applies are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: members of the Commission;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person who is an officer or employee of the Commission;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any person who is a member of any committee of the Commission; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any person who is performing any service for the Commission under a contract of services.

subsection.content: The protection conferred by subsection (1) does not affect any liability of the Commission for the act or omission.
There is established, by virtue of this section, a tribunal to be known as the “Competition Tribunal”. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)
The Tribunal is a superior court of record.
The Tribunal consists of the judges of the Court of First Instance appointed in accordance with section 6 of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4), by virtue of their appointments as such judges.
A Justice of Appeal who sits in the Court of First Instance is not a member of the Tribunal.

The Chief Executive, acting in accordance with the recommendation of the Judicial Officers Recommendation Commission, is to appoint one of the members of the Tribunal to be the President of the Tribunal.
The President is to hold office for a term of at least 3 years, but not more than 5 years, as is stated in his or her letter of appointment, but is eligible for re-appointment.
The President may give directions as to the arrangement of the business of the Tribunal, and is to perform such other functions as are assigned to the President under this Ordinance.

The Chief Executive, acting in accordance with the recommendation of the Judicial Officers Recommendation Commission, is to appoint one of the members of the Tribunal to be the Deputy President of the Tribunal.
The Deputy President is to hold office for a term of at least 3 years, but not more than 5 years, as is stated in his or her letter of appointment, but is eligible for re-appointment.
The Deputy President may, subject to any directions given by the President, perform all the functions of the President.
Every decision or other act or omission of the Deputy President while acting under subsection (3) is to be regarded as a decision, act or omission of the President.
If for any reason the President is unable, whether temporarily or otherwise, to perform the functions of the President, the Deputy President may act as President.

If for any reason the Deputy President is unable, whether temporarily or otherwise, to perform the functions of the President when the President is unable to perform them himself or herself, the Chief Justice may appoint another member of the Tribunal to act as President.
A person acting as President under this section may perform all the functions of the President.
Every decision or other act or omission of a person acting as President under this section is to be regarded as the decision, act or omission of the President.
The Chief Justice may at any time revoke an appointment made under subsection (2).

section.name: s139
section.heading: Resignation as President or Deputy President

subsection.content: The President and Deputy President may, at any time, resign from their office by giving written notice of resignation to the Chief Executive.
If the President or Deputy President resigns from office under this section, he or she continues to be a member of the Tribunal.

section.name: s140
section.heading: Vacancy in office of President or Deputy President

subsection.leadIn: The office of President or Deputy President becomes vacant if the President or Deputy President (as the case may be)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: dies;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ceases to be a judge of the Court of First Instance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is appointed to be a Justice of Appeal, or to a higher judicial office; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: resigns his or her office under section 139.

subsection.content: If the office of President or Deputy President has become vacant, the Chief Executive, acting in accordance with the recommendation of the Judicial Officers Recommendation Commission, is to appoint one of the members of the Tribunal to be the President or Deputy President (as the case requires).

The President or Deputy President appointed under this section is to hold office for a term of at least 3 years, but not more than 5 years, as is stated in his or her letter of appointment, but is eligible for re-appointment.

In any proceedings under this Ordinance, the Tribunal may appoint one or more specially qualified assessors and may dispose of the proceedings, wholly or in part, with the assistance of such assessor or assessors, but the decision of the Tribunal is that of the members of Tribunal only.
The Tribunal may determine the remuneration, if any, to be paid to an assessor appointed under this section, but no remuneration may be paid to an assessor who is a public officer.

An assessor is not personally liable for anything done or omitted to be done by the assessor in good faith in the performance of his or her functions or purported performance of his or her functions under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal has jurisdiction to hear and determine—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: applications made by the Commission with regard to alleged contraventions, or alleged involvements in contraventions, of the competition rules;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: applications for the review of reviewable determinations;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: private actions in respect of contraventions, or involvements in contraventions, of the conduct rules;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: allegations of contraventions, or involvements in contraventions, of the conduct rules raised as a defence;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: applications for the disposal of property;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: applications for the enforcement of commitments; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: any matter related to a matter referred to in paragraph (a), (b), (c), (d), (e) or (f) if the matters arise out of the same or substantially the same facts.

subsection.content: In the exercise of its jurisdiction, the Tribunal has the same jurisdiction to grant remedies and reliefs, equitable or legal, as the Court of First Instance.

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal has, with respect to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the attendance, swearing and examination of witnesses;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the production and inspection of documents;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the enforcement of its orders; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: all other matters necessary for the exercise of its jurisdiction,

subsection.continued: all the powers, rights and privileges of the Court of First Instance. (Amended 15 of 2014 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the scope of subsection (1), in proceedings before the Tribunal, the Tribunal may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: receive and consider any evidence, whether by way of oral evidence, written statements, documents or otherwise, and whether or not it would otherwise be admissible in a court of law;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: determine the manner in which it will receive evidence referred to in paragraph (a);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: by notice in writing, signed by the presiding member of the Tribunal, summon any person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to produce any article or document that is relevant to the proceedings and is in that person’s possession or under that person’s control;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to appear before it and to give any evidence relevant to the proceedings; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: exercise such other powers as may be necessary or ancillary to the conduct of any proceedings.

subsection.content: The Tribunal may decide its own procedures and may, in so far as it thinks fit, follow the practice and procedure of the Court of First Instance in the exercise of its civil jurisdiction, and for this purpose, has the same jurisdiction, powers and duties of the Court in respect of such practice and procedure, including the jurisdiction, powers and duties of the Court in respect of costs.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Tribunal has the same jurisdiction, powers and duties of the Court of First Instance in respect of the punishment of a person guilty of contempt.
The Tribunal is to conduct its proceedings with as much informality as is consistent with attaining justice.

subsection.leadIn: An application to the Tribunal may be heard and determined by a Tribunal constituted by any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the President;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the President and one or more other members appointed by the President; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: one or more other members appointed by the President.

subsection.content: If the President is sitting with one or more other members, the President is to preside over the hearing; if the President is not sitting and there is more than one other member sitting, the President is to appoint one of those other members to preside over the sitting.

Any difference between the members exercising the jurisdiction of the Tribunal is to be decided by majority vote and, in the event of an equality of votes, the member presiding is to have a second or casting vote.

section.name: s146
section.heading: Absence of member during course of proceedings

subsection.leadIn: If, after the commencement of any proceedings, a member of the Tribunal, other than the presiding member, is absent for any reason, the presiding member may, with the consent of the parties—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: direct that the proceedings be continued in the absence of that member; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: direct that another specified member take the place of the absent member in the proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: If, after the commencement of proceedings, the presiding member of the Tribunal is absent for any reason, then—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if there is only one member of the Tribunal remaining, and the parties agree, the proceedings may be continued in the absence of the presiding member; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if there is more than one member of the Tribunal remaining, and the parties agree—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the proceedings may be continued in the absence of the presiding member; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the most senior of the remaining members is to preside, with seniority determined according to the priority of their appointments as judges of the Court of First Instance.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the presiding member has given a direction under subsection (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the members and parties have agreed to proceed under subsection (2),

subsection.continued: the Tribunal as so constituted is to be regarded as properly constituted.

section.name: s147
section.heading: Rules of evidence
section.leadIn: In proceedings under this Ordinance, other than proceedings in which the Commission applies for an order for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a pecuniary penalty under section 93; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a financial penalty under section 169,

section.continued: the Tribunal is not bound by the rules of evidence and may receive and take into account any relevant evidence or information, whether or not it would be otherwise admissible in a court of law.

section.name: s148
section.heading: Evidence that might tend to incriminate

subsection.leadIn: A person appearing before the Tribunal to give evidence, other than in proceedings in which the Commission applies for an order for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a pecuniary penalty under section 93; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a financial penalty under section 169,

subsection.continued: is not excused from answering any question on the grounds that to do so might expose the person to proceedings referred to in subsection (3).

subsection.content: No statement or admission made by a person answering any question put to the person, in any proceedings to which subsection (1) applies, is admissible in evidence against that person in proceedings referred to in subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: The proceedings referred to in subsections (1) and (2) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: proceedings in which the Commission applies for an order for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a pecuniary penalty under section 93; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a financial penalty under section 169; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any criminal proceedings, other than proceedings for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an offence under section 55 (Providing false or misleading documents or information);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an offence under Part V (Perjury) of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200); or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: an offence of perjury.

subsection.leadIn: A finding of fact by the Tribunal, which is relevant to an issue arising in any other proceedings, either in the Tribunal or in the Court of First Instance, relating to a contravention of a conduct rule, is evidence of that fact in those proceedings if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the time for bringing an appeal in respect of the finding has expired and the relevant party has not brought such an appeal; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the final decision of a court on such appeal has confirmed the finding.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to the first conduct rule, a party to the agreement which is the subject of the alleged contravention; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to the second conduct rule, the undertaking whose conduct is alleged to have contravened the conduct rule or any other person involved in the contravention.

section.name: s150
section.heading: Findings of fact by Court of First Instance

subsection.leadIn: A finding of any fact by the Court of First Instance in any proceedings transferred to it by the Tribunal under section 114(3), which is relevant to an issue arising in any other proceedings, either in the Court or in the Tribunal, relating to a contravention, or involvement in a contravention, of a conduct rule, is evidence of that fact in those other proceedings if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the time for bringing an appeal in respect of the finding has expired and the relevant party has not brought such an appeal; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the final decision of a court on such appeal has confirmed the finding.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: relevant party (有關一方) has the meaning given by section 149(2).

subsection.content: The Tribunal may order a person not to publish or otherwise disclose any material the Tribunal receives.
A person who fails to comply with an order made under subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s151A
section.heading: Order prohibiting departure from Hong Kong

def.name: ProhibitionOrder
def.leadIn: The Tribunal may make an order prohibiting a person from leaving Hong Kong (prohibition order)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: to facilitate the enforcement or to secure the compliance of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a judgment or order against the person for the payment of a specified sum of money;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a judgment or order against the person for the payment of an amount to be assessed; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a judgment or order against the person requiring the person to deliver any property or perform any other act; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: to facilitate the pursuance of a civil claim (other than a judgment)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for the payment of money or damages; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: for the delivery of any property or the performance of any other act.

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal must not make a prohibition order against a person under subsection (1)(a)(ii) or (iii) unless it is satisfied that there is probable cause for believing that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person is about to leave Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: because of the circumstance mentioned in paragraph (a), satisfaction of the judgment or order concerned is likely to be obstructed or delayed.

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal must not make a prohibition order against a person under subsection (1)(b) unless it is satisfied that there is probable cause for believing that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is a good cause of action;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: incurred the alleged liability, being the subject of the claim, in Hong Kong while the person was present in Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: carries on business in Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: is ordinarily resident in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person is about to leave Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: because of the circumstance mentioned in paragraph (c), any judgment or order that may be given against the person is likely to be obstructed or delayed.
